Literature Review: Meiosis is a fundamental process in sexual reproduction, characterized by the reduction of chromosome number and genetic recombination. This literature review explores the current understanding of meiotic processes, focusing on homolog interactions, recombination, and the evolutionary origins of meiosis.Homolog pairing is a crucial step in meiosis, ensuring proper chromosome segregation and genetic exchange. Recent studies have shed light on the mechanisms underlying this process. For instance, Zickler and Kleckner (2015) provided an extensive review of homolog pairing across various organisms, highlighting the role of telomere-led chromosome movements in facilitating homolog search and alignment. Additionally, Ding et al. (2019) demonstrated the importance of synaptonemal complex proteins in stabilizing homolog interactions during meiosis in mice.DNA recombination, a hallmark of meiosis, involves the exchange of genetic material between homologous chromosomes. Hunter (2015) reviewed the molecular mechanisms of meiotic recombination, emphasizing the role of double-strand breaks (DSBs) in initiating the process. The formation and repair of DSBs are tightly regulated, as shown by Gray and Cohen (2016), who identified key proteins involved in DSB formation and processing in yeast.Crossover interference, a phenomenon where the occurrence of one crossover reduces the likelihood of another nearby, has been a subject of intense research. Wang et al. (2015) proposed a mechanical stress model to explain crossover interference, suggesting that physical forces along the chromosome axis play a role in regulating crossover distribution. Furthermore, Zhang et al. (2018) identified specific proteins that mediate crossover interference in Arabidopsis, providing insights into the molecular basis of this process.Chiasma maturation, the final step in crossover formation, ensures the stability of physical connections between homologs. Cahoon and Hawley (2016) reviewed the mechanisms of chiasma formation and maintenance, highlighting the importance of cohesion proteins in this process. Their work also emphasized the role of chiasma maturation in preventing premature separation of homologs during meiosis I.The evolution of meiosis from mitosis has been a topic of considerable interest. Wilkins and Holliday (2009) proposed a model for the stepwise evolution of meiosis from mitosis, suggesting that meiosis evolved through modifications of the mitotic cell cycle. Building on this idea, Marston and Amon (2004) compared the molecular mechanisms of chromosome segregation in mitosis and meiosis, identifying key similarities and differences between the two processes.Recent studies have provided evidence supporting the hypothesis that meiosis evolved by coupling recombination complexes to late-stage mitotic chromosome structures. For example, Mercier et al. (2015) reviewed the conservation of meiotic genes across eukaryotes, suggesting that many meiosis-specific proteins evolved from mitotic counterparts. Additionally, Bomblies et al. (2015) explored the evolutionary plasticity of meiosis, highlighting how variations in meiotic processes across species can provide insights into its evolutionary origins.The interaction between recombination complexes and chromosome structures is central to meiotic processes. Zickler and Kleckner (2016) reviewed the organization of meiotic chromosomes, emphasizing the role of chromosome axis proteins in regulating recombination. Furthermore, Kleckner et al. (2004) proposed a model linking chromosome structure to meiotic events, suggesting that mechanical stress along chromosomes influences various aspects of meiosis, including recombination and crossover interference.In conclusion, recent advances in meiosis research have provided significant insights into the mechanisms underlying homolog interactions, recombination, and the evolutionary origins of meiosis. The complex interplay between recombination complexes and chromosome structures emerges as a central theme, supporting the hypothesis that meiosis evolved through modifications of mitotic processes. Future research will undoubtedly continue to unravel the intricacies of meiosis, furthering our understanding of this fundamental biological process.
